intro: Baumannia douglasiana, commonly known as the Douglas's balm, is a flowering plant native to the western United States. It belongs to the Apiaceae family, which includes carrots and parsley, and is characterized by its finely divided, fern-like leaves. The plant produces small, white to pale yellow flowers arranged in umbels, typical of the family. It thrives in moist, well-drained soils and is often found in meadows and along stream banks. Due to its ornamental value and ecological importance, it is sometimes cultivated in gardens.
